The treaty has not been signed by them.
The treaty had not been signed by them.
The treaty is not signed by them.

correctAnswer.en: The treaty had not been signed by them.

explanation.en: The Active Tense is Past Perfect (had not signed). The Passive structure is: Subject + had not been + V3 (signed) + by + Agent.

question.en: Convert to Active Voice: 'The child was being fed by his mother.'

en: His mother was feeding the child.
His mother had fed the child.

correctAnswer.en: His mother was feeding the child.

explanation.en: The Passive structure 'was being + V3' is Past Continuous Tense. The Active structure is: Subject + was/were + V-ing + Object.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The guide said, 'Where are we going tomorrow?'

en: The guide asked where they are going the next day.
The guide asked where they were going the next day.
The guide asked where we were going tomorrow.
The guide asked where they would be going tomorrow.

correctAnswer.en: The guide asked where they were going the next day.

explanation.en: The tense changes from Present Continuous ('are going') to Past Continuous ('were going'). The pronoun 'we' changes to 'they'. The time adverb 'tomorrow' changes to 'the next day'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: The commander ordered his men not to attack that day.

en: The commander said, 'Do not attack that day.'
The commander said, 'Do not attack today.'
The commander asked, 'Why not attack today?'
The commander said, 'You must not attack.'

correctAnswer.en: The commander said, 'Do not attack today.'

explanation.en: The Indirect imperative negative ('ordered not to attack') converts to Direct ('Do not attack'). The time adverb 'that day' changes back to 'today'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The saint said, 'Man is mortal.'

en: The saint said that man was mortal.
The saint said that man is mortal.
The saint announced that man is mortal.
The saint told that man was mortal.

correctAnswer.en: The saint said that man is mortal.

explanation.en: This is a universal truth, so the tense ('is mortal') remains unchanged in Indirect Speech.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: He said, 'I finished my breakfast an hour ago.'

en: He said that he had finished his breakfast an hour before.
He said that he finished his breakfast an hour before.
He said that I finished my breakfast an hour ago.
He said that he had finished his breakfast an hour ago.

correctAnswer.en: He said that he had finished his breakfast an hour before.

explanation.en: Simple Past ('finished') changes to Past Perfect ('had finished'). Adverb 'ago' changes to 'before'. Pronoun 'I' changes to 'he'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: The beggar pleaded for some food.

en: The beggar said, 'Give me some food.'
The beggar pleaded, 'I want some food.'
The beggar said, 'Please give me some food.'
The beggar said, 'Give you some food?'

correctAnswer.en: The beggar said, 'Please give me some food.'

explanation.en: The reporting verb 'pleaded' indicates a polite request. The Direct imperative uses 'Please'. The infinitive 'for some food' becomes 'Give me some food'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: My teacher said to me, 'You must work hard.'

en: My teacher ordered me to work hard.
My teacher advised me to work hard.
My teacher told me that I must work hard.
Both B and C are correct.

correctAnswer.en: Both B and C are correct.

explanation.en: The modal 'must' often implies advice, so 'advised to' is correct. Alternatively, 'must' can remain 'must' in reported speech when expressing a fixed necessity or duty. Pronoun 'You' changes to 'I'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: They asked the stranger what his name was.

en: They said to the stranger, 'What your name is?'
They said to the stranger, 'What is your name?'
They asked the stranger, 'What was your name?'
They asked the stranger, 'What his name was?'

correctAnswer.en: They said to the stranger, 'What is your name?'

explanation.en: The Indirect is a WH-question. Past Tense ('was') converts to Present Tense ('is'). Pronoun 'his' changes to 'your'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The watchman said, 'I have been standing here for three hours.'

en: The watchman said that he has been standing there for three hours.
The watchman said that he had been standing there for three hours.
The watchman told that he had been standing here for three hours.
The watchman said that I had been standing there for three hours.

correctAnswer.en: The watchman said that he had been standing there for three hours.

explanation.en: Present Perfect Continuous ('have been standing') changes to Past Perfect Continuous ('had been standing'). Adverb 'here' changes to 'there'. Pronoun 'I' changes to 'he'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The boys shouted, 'Hurrah! We have won the trophy.'

en: The boys shouted that they had won the trophy.
The boys exclaimed with joy that they had won the trophy.
The boys exclaimed with joy that we have won the trophy.
The boys said with happiness that they won the trophy.

correctAnswer.en: The boys exclaimed with joy that they had won the trophy.

explanation.en: The interjection 'Hurrah!' requires the reporting verb 'exclaimed with joy'. Present Perfect ('have won') changes to Past Perfect ('had won'). Pronoun 'We' changes to 'they'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: The doctor asked the patient how he was feeling then.

en: The doctor said to the patient, 'How are you feeling now?'
The doctor asked the patient, 'How was he feeling now?'
The doctor asked the patient, 'How are you feeling then?'
The doctor said, 'How are you feeling?'

correctAnswer.en: The doctor said to the patient, 'How are you feeling now?'

explanation.en: Past Continuous ('was feeling') converts to Present Continuous ('are you feeling'). The time adverb 'then' changes back to 'now'. Pronoun 'he' changes to 'you'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: He said to his friend, 'Please lend me your book.'

en: He requested his friend to lend him his book.
He asked his friend if he would lend him his book.
He requested his friend to lend me his book.
He told his friend to lend him his book.

correctAnswer.en: He requested his friend to lend him his book.

explanation.en: The imperative with 'Please' requires the reporting verb 'requested' + infinitive ('to lend'). Pronoun 'me' changes to 'him'. Adjective 'your' changes to 'his'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: The children said that they loved those stories.

en: The children said, 'We love these stories.'
The children said, 'They love those stories.'
The children said, 'We loved those stories.'
The children said, 'We love those stories.'

correctAnswer.en: The children said, 'We love these stories.'

explanation.en: Simple Past ('loved') converts to Simple Present ('love'). Demonstrative 'those' changes back to 'these'. Pronoun 'they' changes back to 'we'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: She said, 'I had been studying all day.'

en: She said that she had been studying all day.
She said that she was studying all day.
She told that she had studied all day.
She said that I had been studying all day.

correctAnswer.en: She said that she had been studying all day.

explanation.en: Past Perfect Continuous Tense ('had been studying') does not change in Indirect Speech. Pronoun 'I' changes to 'she'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: My boss said, 'You may leave early today.'

en: My boss said that I might leave early that day.
My boss told me that I may leave early today.
My boss informed that I might leave early today.
My boss said that he might leave early that day.

correctAnswer.en: My boss said that I might leave early that day.

explanation.en: Modal 'may' changes to 'might'. Pronoun 'You' changes to 'I' (assuming the listener is me). Time adverb 'today' changes to 'that day'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: The customer complained that the price was too high.

en: The customer said, 'The price is too high.'
The customer said, 'The price was too high.'
The customer complained, 'The price is too high.'
The customer said, 'The price is being too high.'

correctAnswer.en: The customer said, 'The price is too high.'

explanation.en: The reporting verb 'complained' converts to 'said'. The Past Tense ('was') converts back to Simple Present ('is').

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The teacher said to the students, 'Have you done your homework?'

en: The teacher asked the students if they had done their homework.
The teacher asked the students if they have done their homework.
The teacher asked the students whether you had done your homework.
The teacher enquired if the students had done his homework.

correctAnswer.en: The teacher asked the students if they had done their homework.

explanation.en: The question is a Yes/No type, so 'if/whether' is used. Present Perfect ('Have done') changes to Past Perfect ('had done'). Pronoun 'you' changes to 'they'. Adjective 'your' changes to 'their'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: She wished me good luck.

en: She said to me, 'Wish you good luck.'
She said, 'I wish you good luck.'
She said to me, 'May you have good luck!'

explanation.en: Expressions of wishes are converted back directly. 'Wished me good luck' is the indirect form of the direct exclamation 'Good luck!'

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The tourist said, 'It is very cold here.'

en: The tourist said that it was very cold here.
The tourist said that it is very cold there.
The tourist said that it was very cold there.
The tourist told that it was very cold there.

correctAnswer.en: The tourist said that it was very cold there.

explanation.en: Simple Present ('is') changes to Simple Past ('was'). Adverb 'here' changes to 'there'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: I said to him, 'Did you complete the project?'

en: I asked him if he completed the project.
I asked him if he had completed the project.
I asked him if you completed the project.
I asked him whether he did complete the project.

correctAnswer.en: I asked him if he had completed the project.

explanation.en: The question is a Yes/No type, so 'if' is used. Simple Past ('Did complete') changes to Past Perfect ('had completed'). Pronoun 'you' changes to 'he'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: My father forbade me to waste time.

en: My father said, 'You should not waste time.'
My father said, 'Do not waste time.'
My father warned, 'Wasting time is bad.'
My father said, 'You must not waste time.'

correctAnswer.en: My father said, 'Do not waste time.'

explanation.en: The reporting verb 'forbade' is used for a negative command. The Direct imperative negative is 'Do not + V1'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: The beggar said, 'How wonderful my luck is!'

en: The beggar exclaimed that his luck was wonderful.
The beggar exclaimed how wonderful his luck was.
The beggar said that his luck was very wonderful.
The beggar exclaimed with surprise that his luck was wonderful.

correctAnswer.en: The beggar exclaimed how wonderful his luck was.

explanation.en: Exclamatory sentence uses 'exclaimed'. Simple Present ('is') changes to Simple Past ('was'). Pronoun 'my' changes to 'his'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: She requested me to give her a glass of water.

en: She said to me, 'Will you give me a glass of water?'
She said to me, 'Please give me a glass of water.'
She asked me, 'Can you give her a glass of water?'
She said, 'Give me a glass of water.'

correctAnswer.en: She said to me, 'Please give me a glass of water.'

explanation.en: The reporting verb 'requested' implies a polite imperative command. The Direct form uses 'Please'. Pronoun 'her' changes back to 'me'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: He said, 'I shall go to London next week.'

en: He said that he should go to London next week.
He said that he would go to London the following week.
He told that he shall go to London the next week.
He said that he will go to London the following week.

correctAnswer.en: He said that he would go to London the following week.

explanation.en: Modal 'shall' changes to 'would' (since the subject changes from 'I' to 'he'). Time adverb 'next week' changes to 'the following week'.

question.en: Convert to Indirect Speech: They said, 'We must leave by tonight.'

en: They said that they must leave by tonight.
They said that they had to leave by that night.
They said that they should leave by that night.
Both A and B are correct.

correctAnswer.en: They said that they had to leave by that night.

explanation.en: The modal 'must' (indicating obligation) usually changes to 'had to'. The time adverb 'tonight' changes to 'that night'. Pronoun 'We' changes to 'they'.

question.en: Convert to Direct Speech: The officer asked the clerk to show him those files.

en: The officer said to the clerk, 'Show me those files.'
The officer said to the clerk, 'Show me these files.'
The officer asked the clerk, 'Will you show me those files?'
The officer said to the clerk, 'Show him these files.'

correctAnswer.en: The officer said to the clerk, 'Show me these files.'

explanation.en: The Indirect imperative ('asked/ordered to show') converts to the Direct imperative. Pronoun 'him' changes back to 'me'. Demonstrative 'those' changes back to 'these'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Neither of the two candidates / have paid / their subscription. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Indefinite pronouns like 'Neither', 'Either', 'Each', 'Every one of' always take a singular verb. 'have paid' should be 'has paid'. The pronoun 'their' is also incorrect; it should be 'his' or 'his/her'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The quality of the products _____ not been good.'

explanation.en: When a singular subject ('The quality') is joined to a plural noun ('the products') by a preposition ('of'), the verb agrees with the main subject ('quality'), which is singular. Thus, 'has' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Two thousand rupees / are too much / for this piece of cloth. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: When a plural noun (money/distance/weight) is considered a single unit (here, a single amount), it takes a singular verb. 'are too much' should be 'is too much'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The committee _____ divided on this issue.'

explanation.en: Rule: Collective nouns ('committee', 'jury', 'team') take a plural verb when the members are acting separately or are divided. 'Divided' implies separate actions/opinions, requiring the plural verb 'were'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'More than one student / have failed / in the final examination. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'More than one' followed by a singular noun ('student') takes a singular verb. 'have failed' should be 'has failed'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Bread and butter _____ his only food.'

explanation.en: Rule: When two singular subjects are joined by 'and' but express a single idea, they take a singular verb. 'Bread and butter' refers to one combined dish or staple food. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Physics / are a difficult / subject for many students. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns that look plural but refer to a single entity (like subjects, e.g., 'Physics', 'Mathematics', 'Economics') take a singular verb. 'are a difficult' should be 'is a difficult'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Not only the manager but also his employees _____ arrived.'

explanation.en: Rule: When subjects are joined by 'not only... but also', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it ('his employees', which is plural). Thus, 'have' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'A number of soldiers / was killed / in the recent war. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'A number of' (meaning many) takes a plural verb. 'was killed' should be 'were killed'. (Contrast with 'The number of' which is singular).

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Everyone of the participants _____ been given a certificate.'

explanation.en: Rule: Indefinite pronouns like 'Everyone', 'Each', 'Either', 'Neither' always take a singular verb. Thus, 'has' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The Arabian Nights / are a collection / of stories for children. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Titles of books, movies, countries, etc., even if they are plural in form, take a singular verb. 'The Arabian Nights' is one book. 'are a collection' should be 'is a collection'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The ship, with its crew members, _____ sailing smoothly.'

explanation.en: Rule: When a subject ('The ship') is joined by phrases like 'with', 'along with', 'as well as', 'in addition to', the verb agrees with the first subject ('The ship'), which is singular. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'One of the best athletes / who has trained / for the Olympics is Rohan. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'One of the' is followed by a relative pronoun ('who'), the verb in the relative clause agrees with the plural noun preceding 'who' ('athletes'). 'has trained' should be 'have trained'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Either the principal or the teachers _____ responsible for the decision.'

explanation.en: Rule: When subjects are joined by 'either... or' or 'neither... nor', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it ('the teachers', which is plural). Thus, 'are' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'If I was / the King, I would / abolish all taxes. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: In conditional clauses expressing an unreal or hypothetical situation (Subjunctive Mood), the verb 'to be' always takes the plural form 'were', regardless of the subject. 'If I was' should be 'If I were'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Mumps _____ a contagious disease.'

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns that look plural but refer to a single disease (e.g., 'Mumps', 'Measles') take a singular verb. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Three-fourths of the land / are barren / and unfit for cultivation. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: With fractional expressions ('three-fourths of'), the verb agrees with the noun that follows the preposition ('land'), which is an uncountable (singular) noun. 'are barren' should be 'is barren'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Justice, as well as mercy, _____ required.'

explanation.en: Rule: When a subject ('Justice') is joined by 'as well as', 'with', 'along with', the verb agrees with the first subject, which is singular ('Justice'). Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The team / are arguing / among themselves over the strategy. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The use of the plural verb 'are' is correct here because the context ('among themselves') implies that the collective noun 'team' is acting as separate individuals. The sentence has No Error.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Many a small business _____ failed this year.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'Many a' is always followed by a singular noun ('business') and takes a singular verb. Thus, 'has' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'News of the success / have brought / him great joy. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The noun 'News' is always uncountable and takes a singular verb. 'have brought' should be 'has brought'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The majority of the students _____ in favor of the trip.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'majority' refers to a number of people, it takes a plural verb. Since 'students' is plural, the verb should be plural. Thus, 'are' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'If the report was / true, the politician / would lose his seat. / No Error.'

en: would lose his seat. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The structure 'If + Simple Past + would + V1' implies an unreal or hypothetical condition (Second Conditional). The Subjunctive mood requires 'were' instead of 'was'. 'If the report was' should be 'If the report were'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Neither Riya nor her parents _____ at home.'

explanation.en: Rule: When subjects are joined by 'neither... nor', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it ('her parents', which is plural). Thus, 'were' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'A pair of shoes / were lying / in the corner of the room. / No Error.'

en: in the corner of the room.

explanation.en: Rule: The true subject is 'A pair' (singular), and 'of shoes' is a prepositional phrase. 'were lying' should be 'was lying'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The crowd _____ shouting slogans against the government.'

explanation.en: Rule: Collective nouns like 'crowd', 'army' take a singular verb when acting as a unit. 'Shouting slogans' is a unified action. Thus, 'was' is correct. (If the focus was on individual shouting, 'were' would be used).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'What he says / and what he does / are often misunderstood. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Two infinitive phrases ('What he says' and 'what he does') joined by 'and' represent two separate concepts and thus take a plural verb. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Rice and curry _____ his favorite dish.'

explanation.en: Rule: When two singular subjects joined by 'and' express a single idea/dish, they take a singular verb. 'Rice and curry' is one combined dish. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Our happiness / or our sorrow / are largely due to our own actions. / No Error.'

en: are largely due to our own actions. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: are largely due to our own actions. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: When subjects are joined by 'or', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it ('our sorrow', which is singular). 'are largely' should be 'is largely'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Mathematics _____ his most difficult subject.'

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns that look plural but refer to a single subject ('Mathematics') take a singular verb. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Slow and steady / win / the race. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Two singular subjects joined by 'and' take a singular verb when they refer to a single concept or proverb. 'Slow and steady' refers to a single method. 'win' (plural) should be 'wins' (singular).

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The number of accidents _____ increasing every year.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'The number of' (meaning the quantity) always takes a singular verb. Thus, 'is' is correct. (Contrast with 'A number of').

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Not only the students / but also the teacher / were enjoying the show. / No Error.'

en: were enjoying the show. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: were enjoying the show. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: When subjects are joined by 'not only... but also', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it ('the teacher', which is singular). 'were enjoying' should be 'was enjoying'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Twenty miles _____ a long distance to walk.'

explanation.en: Rule: Plural subjects denoting a single distance, time, or amount take a singular verb when considered as one unit. 'Twenty miles' is considered a single distance. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The furniture / of the house / are new. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The noun 'furniture' is uncountable and always singular. 'are new' should be 'is new'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Most of the money _____ spent on repairs.'

explanation.en: Rule: With expressions like 'Most of', 'Some of', 'All of', the verb agrees with the noun that follows the preposition ('money'), which is uncountable (singular). Thus, 'was' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The general, with all his soldiers, / were killed / in the battle. / No Error.'

en: The general, with all his soldiers,

explanation.en: Rule: When a subject ('The general') is joined by 'with', 'along with', the verb agrees with the first subject, which is singular. 'were killed' should be 'was killed'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Either you or I _____ to blame.'

explanation.en: Rule: When subjects are joined by 'either... or', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it ('I'). Thus, 'am' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'No one / except the students / are allowed to enter the hall. / No Error.'

en: are allowed to enter the hall. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: are allowed to enter the hall. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Indefinite pronouns like 'No one' are always singular. The phrase 'except the students' is a prepositional phrase and does not affect the verb. 'are allowed' should be 'is allowed'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The percentage of failed students _____ high this year.'

explanation.en: Rule: The subject is 'The percentage' (singular), not the students. The verb must be singular. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The poet and writer / have died / and will be remembered forever. / No Error.'

en: and will be remembered forever. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: If two nouns joined by 'and' are preceded by only one article ('The poet and writer'), they refer to the same person. Hence, the verb must be singular. 'have died' should be 'has died'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Ten kilometers _____ a short walk for him.'

explanation.en: Rule: Plural subjects denoting a single distance, time, or amount take a singular verb when considered as one unit. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'A large number of vehicles / is still / seen on the roads today. / No Error.'

en: seen on the roads today. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'A number of' (meaning many) takes a plural verb. 'is still' should be 'are still'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Nobody _____ aware of the secret plan.'

explanation.en: Rule: Indefinite pronouns like 'Nobody', 'Somebody', 'Everyone', 'Something' are always singular. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The jury / were unanimous / in its verdict. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The collective noun 'jury' is acting as a unit ('unanimous' and followed by singular pronoun 'its'). Therefore, it must take a singular verb. 'were unanimous' should be 'was unanimous'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Neither of them _____ present at the meeting.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Neither of' always takes a singular verb. Thus, 'was' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The police / is investigating / the latest bank robbery. / No Error.'

en: the latest bank robbery. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns like 'police', 'people', 'cattle' are always treated as plural subjects. 'is investigating' should be 'are investigating'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'The famous scientist and writer _____ arriving tonight.'

explanation.en: Rule: Only one article ('The') preceding two nouns indicates that they refer to the same person. Hence, the verb must be singular. Thus, 'is' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'All the furniture / have been / delivered to the new office. / No Error.'

en: delivered to the new office. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The noun 'furniture' is uncountable and always singular. 'have been' should be 'has been'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'A majority of the votes _____ against the proposal.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'majority' is used in a specific context like 'votes', it can be treated as a single entity, especially when referring to the bulk of the opinion/count. Both singular ('was') and plural ('were') are sometimes used, but singular is generally preferred for the count itself.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Economics / are still / a mandatory subject in college. / No Error.'

en: a mandatory subject in college. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns that look plural but refer to a single subject ('Economics') take a singular verb. 'are still' should be 'is still'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'There _____ many books on the table.'

explanation.en: Rule: When a sentence starts with 'There' or 'Here', the verb agrees with the true subject that follows it ('many books', which is plural). Thus, 'are' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'What I want / is a pair of spectacles. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The noun clause 'What I want' is treated as a singular subject. The verb 'is' agrees with the singular noun clause. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Every single teacher and student _____ present at the annual function.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'Every' or 'Each' precedes the subjects (even if joined by 'and'), the verb must be singular. Thus, 'was' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The trousers / that you bought / looks too big on you. / No Error.'

en: looks too big on you. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: looks too big on you. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns that refer to items with two parts (e.g., 'trousers', 'scissors', 'spectacles') are always plural and take a plural verb. 'looks' (singular) should be 'look' (plural).

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Most of the employees _____ in favor of the new policy.'

explanation.en: Rule: With expressions like 'Most of', the verb agrees with the noun that follows the preposition ('employees'), which is plural. Thus, 'were' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Only one of the students / who was present / in the class passed the test. / No Error.'

en: in the class passed the test. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The inclusion of 'Only' makes 'One' the actual antecedent of the relative pronoun 'who'. Thus, the singular verb 'was' in the relative clause is correct. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Every boy and every girl _____ given a prize.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'Every' or 'Each' precedes the subjects (even if joined by 'and'), the verb must be singular. Thus, 'was' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'To climb the mountains / are a great / challenge for an average person. / No Error.'

en: challenge for an average person. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The subject is the infinitive phrase ('To climb the mountains'), which is always treated as singular. 'are a great' should be 'is a great'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Some of the luggage _____ missing.'

explanation.en: Rule: The verb agrees with the noun that follows the preposition ('luggage'), which is an uncountable (singular) noun. Thus, 'was' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'If I were / a millionaire, I will / start a college for the poor. / No Error.'

en: start a college for the poor. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: This is a Type 2 or Unreal Past Conditional (Hypothetical condition in the present). Structure: If + Simple Past (or Subjunctive 'were'), Main Clause: Subject + 'would' + V1. 'I will' should be 'I would'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'If he had started earlier, he _____ reached the station in time.'

explanation.en: Rule: This is a Type 3 or Past Unreal Conditional (Impossible condition in the past). Structure: If + Past Perfect, Main Clause: Subject + 'would have' + V3. Thus, 'would have' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'When she will come, / I will introduce / her to my family. / No Error.'

en: her to my family. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: In time/conditional clauses (starting with 'when', 'if', 'as soon as', 'until', 'before') referring to the future, Simple Present Tense is used, not Future Tense. 'When she will come' should be 'When she comes'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The criminal was heard / to laugh / loudly at the verdict. / No Error.'

en: loudly at the verdict. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Verbs of perception ('hear', 'see', 'watch') are followed by the Bare Infinitive (V1) in Active Voice and the Full Infinitive ('to' + V1) in Passive Voice. Since the sentence is in Passive Voice ('was heard'), 'to laugh' is correct. The sentence has No Error.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'I wish I _____ rich, I would buy a villa.'

explanation.en: Rule: After 'I wish' expressing an unreal/hypothetical condition in the present, the Subjunctive Mood is used. The verb 'to be' always takes 'were', regardless of the subject. Thus, 'were' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Before the police / arrived, the thief / had disappeared. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: This is a Mixed Past and Future Conditional structure. When two past actions occur, the earlier action takes Past Perfect ('had disappeared'), and the later action takes Simple Past ('arrived'). The sentence is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'I prefer / to read / than watching television. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Parallel structure is required. When 'prefer' is followed by an infinitive ('to read'), the comparison should also use an infinitive or, more simply, parallel form. 'than watching' should be 'to watch'. If the comparison uses 'to' + V1, the comparison marker is 'to', not 'than', but here the structure is incorrect. Correct: 'I prefer reading to watching television' or 'I prefer to read rather than watch television'. The error is in the structure 'than watching television'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'If you heat ice, it _____ into water.'

explanation.en: Rule: This is a Zero Conditional (General truth/scientific fact). Structure: If + Simple Present, Main Clause: Simple Present. Thus, 'turns' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Had she work / harder, she would / have secured a better rank. / No Error.'

en: have secured a better rank. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: This is an inverted Type 3 Conditional. The structure should be 'Had + Subject + V3'. 'work' (V1) should be 'worked' (V3). Correct: 'Had she worked harder...'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'I look forward / to meet / you next week. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'look forward to' is a phrasal verb, and the 'to' is a preposition, not part of an infinitive. Prepositions are followed by a Gerund (V-ing). 'to meet' should be 'to meeting'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Unless you _____ me, I will not let you go.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Unless' is a conditional conjunction (Type 1 Conditional). The clause with 'unless' uses Simple Present ('apologize'), and the main clause uses Simple Future ('will not let'). Also, 'unless' already implies negativity, so 'don't apologize' is redundant/incorrect.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'He stopped / smoke / after the doctor warned him. / No Error.'

en: after the doctor warned him. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'stop' takes a Gerund (V-ing) when it means to cease an activity. 'smoke' should be 'smoking'. (If it meant stopping one thing to do another, 'to smoke' would be used, but here 'ceasing' is the intent).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'If the drought / continues, we will / have starved by next year. / No Error.'

en: have starved by next year. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: have starved by next year. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Type 1 Conditional. If + Simple Present ('continues'), Main Clause: Simple Future ('will' + V1). 'will have starved' (Future Perfect) is incorrect or grammatically complex here; it should be 'will starve'. If the future perfect is intended, the condition must be 'If the drought continues **for too long**'. Considering the simplest error: 'will have starved' should be 'will starve'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'It is no use _____ over split milk.'

explanation.en: Rule: The idiom/phrase 'It is no use' or 'It is no good' is always followed by a Gerund (V-ing). Thus, 'crying' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Supposing if / you miss the flight, / what will you do? / No Error.'

en: what will you do? / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Supposing' and 'If' are conditional conjunctions that have similar meanings. Using both together is redundant and grammatically incorrect. One must be removed. 'Supposing if' should be just 'Supposing' or 'If'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'She is used to / travel / by bus every day. / No Error.'

en: by bus every day. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'be used to' (meaning accustomed to) is followed by a Gerund (V-ing). 'travel' should be 'travelling'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He would have joined the company if he _____ the salary acceptable.'

explanation.en: Rule: The main clause is 'would have joined' (Subject + would have + V3), indicating a Type 3 Conditional. The If-clause must use Past Perfect. Structure: If + Past Perfect, Main Clause: Subject + would have + V3. Thus, 'had found' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'I remember / seeing / him somewhere, but I cannot recall the place. / No Error.'

en: him somewhere, but I cannot recall the place. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'remember' can be followed by a Gerund ('seeing') when referring to an action that happened in the past. The sentence is grammatically correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'If I was / the prime minister, I would / focus on employment. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: This is a Type 2 Conditional (Unreal Past/Subjunctive Mood). The verb 'to be' always takes 'were' in this type of hypothetical 'If' clause, regardless of the subject. 'If I was' should be 'If I were'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He avoids _____ public speeches.'

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'avoid' is typically followed by a Gerund (V-ing). Thus, 'giving' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Unless you do not / accept the offer, / I cannot help you. / No Error.'

en: I cannot help you. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Unless' already means 'If... not'. Using 'unless' with 'do not' creates a double negative, which is incorrect. 'Unless you do not' should be 'Unless you accept' or 'If you do not accept'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'We were forbidden / enter / the restricted area. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'forbid' (Passive 'were forbidden') is generally followed by the Full Infinitive ('to' + V1). 'enter' should be 'to enter'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'If you _____ well, you will pass the exam.'

explanation.en: Rule: This is a Type 1 Conditional (Real condition in the present/future). Structure: If + Simple Present, Main Clause: Simple Future ('will pass'). Thus, 'study' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'I am not used to / hear / such crude remarks. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase 'be used to' (am not used to) requires a Gerund (V-ing). 'hear' should be 'hearing'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Had they invited / me, I would / come. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: This is an inverted Type 3 Conditional (Had + Subject + V3, Main Clause: Subject + would have + V3). 'I would come' should be 'I would have come'. 'come' (V1) should be 'have come' (V3). The error is in the main clause.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'We decided _____ the concert next week.'

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'decide' is typically followed by the Full Infinitive ('to' + V1). Thus, 'to attend' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Provided that / he is on time, we / will start the ceremony. / No Error.'

en: will start the ceremony. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Provided that' is a correct conditional conjunction meaning 'on the condition that'. The structure is a correct Type 1 Conditional (Simple Present, Simple Future). The sentence is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'She stopped to talk / to the children / on her way home. / No Error.'

en: on her way home. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'stop' followed by the Full Infinitive ('to talk') means stopping one activity (e.g., walking) in order to do another (talking). The sentence is grammatically correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'We felt the earth _____ under our feet.'

explanation.en: Rule: Verbs of perception ('feel', 'see', 'hear') are followed by either the Bare Infinitive (for the completed action) or the Present Participle/Gerund (for the ongoing action). 'shaking' (Present Participle) is appropriate for an action felt while it was happening.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'If the team / had lost the match, / the crowd will be angry. / No Error.'

en: the crowd will be angry. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: the crowd will be angry. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The If-clause uses Past Perfect ('had lost'), indicating a Type 3 Conditional. The main clause must be Subject + 'would have' + V3. 'will be angry' should be 'would have been angry'. This is a common error: using Future Tense in a Past Unreal Conditional.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'He is / an M.L.A. / and a close friend of mine. / No Error.'

en: and a close friend of mine. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'M.L.A.' is an abbreviation that starts with a consonant letter but has a vowel sound ('Em'), requiring 'an'. The second part 'a close friend' is also correct. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'She lives on _____ outskirts of the city.'

explanation.en: Rule: Phrases like 'outskirts', 'edge', 'center' (when specifying a place) are specific and require the definite article 'the'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Sun rises / in east / and sets in west. / No Error.'

en: and sets in west. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Heavenly bodies (Sun, Moon, Earth) and Cardinal Directions (East, West, North, South) take the definite article 'the'. 'Sun rises' should be 'The Sun rises'. (Also, 'in east' should be 'in the east' and 'in west' should be 'in the west' - assuming the error is to be marked in the first error spot).

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He went to _____ school to meet the principal.'

explanation.en: Rule: If the purpose of visiting an institution (school, hospital, church) is *not* primary (e.g., studying, treatment), the definite article 'the' is used. He went as a visitor, not as a student, so 'the school' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Wisdom is / a gift / of nature. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Abstract nouns like 'Wisdom', 'Honesty', 'Truth' are used without any article (Zero Article) when used in a general sense. 'Wisdom is' is correct, but 'a gift' (countable) is correct only if it is a specific gift. However, 'Wisdom' itself being the subject is used generally, so 'No Error' is often correct if 'a gift' is considered appropriate. **Re-evaluating based on common SSC errors:** Abstract nouns (Wisdom) in general use take Zero Article. The sentence is grammatically acceptable as 'a gift of nature' is a common phrase. Let's assume the question intends to test the Zero Article rule for 'Wisdom' (which is correct here) and **no error** exists.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Give me _____ one-rupee note.'

explanation.en: Rule: Although 'one' starts with the vowel letter 'o', the pronunciation starts with the consonant sound 'w' ('wun'). Thus, the indefinite article 'a' is used.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The Ganga is / a sacred / river in India. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Rivers take 'the' ('The Ganga'). Countable singular nouns with adjectives take 'a/an' ('a sacred river'). The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He is _____ honest person.'

explanation.en: Rule: The adjective 'honest' starts with the consonant letter 'h' but is pronounced with a vowel sound ('o' as in 'onest'). Thus, 'an' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'He is the best / poet and the philosopher / of this generation. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: If two titles/nouns refer to the same person, the article should be used only before the first noun. Since 'the best' is already used, 'the philosopher' is redundant and implies two people. 'the philosopher' should be removed, leaving 'poet and philosopher'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'I prefer _____ silence to noise.'

explanation.en: Rule: Abstract nouns ('silence', 'noise', 'happiness') are used without articles (Zero Article) when used in a general sense. Here, silence is being generally preferred over noise.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'French defeated / the Germans / in the battle. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: When an article is used before a nationality adjective, it refers to the entire people of that nation. 'French' (adjective) needs 'the' to mean 'the people of France'. 'French defeated' should be 'The French defeated'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'We went to _____ hospital to visit a patient.'

explanation.en: Rule: The primary purpose of the hospital is treatment. Since the purpose of the visit is secondary (visiting a patient), the definite article 'the' is used.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The man is / mortal, and everyone / knows this fact. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'man' or 'woman' is used to represent the entire human race (in a general sense), no article (Zero Article) is used. 'The man is' should be 'Man is'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'She is _____ unique dancer.'

explanation.en: Rule: Although 'unique' starts with the vowel letter 'u', the pronunciation starts with the consonant sound 'y' ('yoonique'). Thus, 'a' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'I am reading / a book on / the Mahabharata. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The names of epics and sacred books (like Ramayana, Mahabharata) take the definite article 'the'. 'A book' is a countable singular noun. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'They elected him _____ chairman of the committee.'

explanation.en: Rule: Nouns of title/position (chairman, president, mayor, commander) that follow verbs like 'elect', 'appoint', 'make', 'name', 'declare' are used without any article (Zero Article).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'He plays / the football / every evening. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Names of games/sports (football, cricket, hockey, tennis) do not take any article (Zero Article). 'the football' should be 'football'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: '_____ gold is a precious metal.'

explanation.en: Rule: Material nouns (gold, silver, water, iron) are generally used without any article (Zero Article) when used in a general sense.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Honesty / is a best / policy to follow. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Superlative degree adjectives ('best', 'highest', 'most') always take the definite article 'the'. 'a best' should be 'the best'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He is _____ tallest boy in the class.'

explanation.en: Rule: Superlative degree adjectives ('tallest') are preceded by the definite article 'the'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'She gave me / an one-day leave / for the festival. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'One-day' starts with the consonant sound 'w' ('wun'). 'an one-day' should be 'a one-day'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'I bought _____ lot of books yesterday.'

explanation.en: Rule: The phrase is 'a lot of', which means many. It is a fixed idiomatic phrase.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The science / has solved many / problems of mankind. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Names of subjects/branches of knowledge (Science, History, Biology) do not take an article (Zero Article) when used in a general sense. 'The science' should be 'Science'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: '_____ English is spoken in many countries.'

explanation.en: Rule: Names of languages (English, Hindi, French) do not take an article (Zero Article) when referring to the language itself. (If 'The English' is used, it refers to the people of England).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Every day he goes / to the church / for prayer. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: When the purpose of visiting an institution (church, prison, temple) is primary (prayer/worship), no article is used (Zero Article). 'to the church' should be 'to church'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He is _____ heir to a large fortune.'

explanation.en: Rule: The word 'heir' starts with the silent 'h' and is pronounced with a vowel sound ('air'). Thus, 'an' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The beauty / of the Taj Mahal / is breathtaking. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: Abstract nouns take 'the' when they are particularized by a following phrase or clause (here, 'of the Taj Mahal'). The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He is _____ unfortunate to lose his wallet.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Unfortunate' is an adjective, and there is no singular countable noun following it. Articles are not used before uncountable nouns or adjectives unless they modify a following countable noun.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The poor / are suffering / from lack of shelter. / No Error.'

en: from lack of shelter. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'The' + adjective ('the poor', 'the rich', 'the brave') refers to the entire class of people and is treated as a plural noun. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'We reached _____ summit of the mountain.'

explanation.en: Rule: Phrases referring to specific geographical positions like 'summit', 'top', 'bottom', 'peak' require the definite article 'the'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'What / a pleasant / weather it is! / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The noun 'weather' is an uncountable noun. Uncountable nouns do not take the indefinite article 'a/an'. 'a pleasant weather' should be 'pleasant weather'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'Do you play _____ violin?'

explanation.en: Rule: Names of musical instruments (violin, guitar, piano) take the definite article 'the' when used in the context of playing them.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'He has taken / a meal / just now. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Meal' is a countable singular noun. 'A meal' is correct. The sentence is grammatically correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He goes to _____ bed at 10 p.m.'

explanation.en: Rule: When 'bed', 'school', 'hospital' are used for their primary purpose (sleeping in bed), no article (Zero Article) is used. 'Go to bed' is an idiom.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'All the students / of a class / must submit their assignment. / No Error.'

en: must submit their assignment. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: The use of 'All the students' suggests a specific, known class. 'of a class' (meaning any class) is ambiguous; it should be 'of the class' (meaning the specific class they belong to).

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'I saw _____ blind man crossing the road.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Blind man' is a countable singular noun mentioned for the first time. The pronunciation of 'blind' is consonant, so 'a' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The life / of the poor / is full of hardships. / No Error.'

en: is full of hardships. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: Although 'life' (abstract noun) generally takes Zero Article, it is particularized by the phrase 'of the poor'. Thus, 'The life' is correct. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He waited for me for _____ hour.'

explanation.en: Rule: The word 'hour' starts with the silent 'h' and is pronounced with a vowel sound ('our'). Thus, 'an' is correct.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The honesty / is a quality / that everyone admires. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Honesty' (abstract noun) is used in a general sense here, as 'a quality'. It should take Zero Article. 'The honesty' should be 'Honesty'.

question.en: Fill in the blank: 'He is _____ second person to solve the puzzle.'

explanation.en: Rule: Ordinal numbers ('first', 'second', 'third', 'last') are always preceded by the definite article 'the'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'You are going to the party, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The statement is positive ('You are going'), so the tag must be negative. The auxiliary verb is 'are', and the subject is 'you'. Tag: aren't you.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'He hasn't finished his work, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The statement is negative ('hasn't finished'), so the tag must be positive. The auxiliary verb is 'has', and the subject is 'he'. Tag: has he.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'They live in Mumbai, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The statement is in Simple Present (positive). When there is no auxiliary, use 'do/does/did'. Since the subject is 'They' and the tense is Simple Present, use 'do'. The tag is negative: don't they.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'She rarely comes late, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: Words like 'rarely', 'seldom', 'hardly', 'never', 'no one' make the statement negative, so the tag must be positive. The statement is Simple Present, so use 'does'. Tag: does she.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Let's go for a walk, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: For sentences starting with 'Let's' (meaning Let us, an offer/suggestion), the fixed question tag is 'shall we'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Open the door, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: For imperative sentences (commands or requests) in the positive, the tag is usually 'will you' or 'won't you'. 'Will you' is a more common and polite request.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'I am right, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: For the positive statement 'I am', the negative tag is a mandatory exception: 'aren't I' (since 'amn't' is not used in standard English).

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Somebody called the police, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: Indefinite pronouns like 'somebody', 'everyone', 'no one' are replaced by the pronoun 'they' in the question tag. The statement is Simple Past (positive), so the tag is negative 'didn't they'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Nothing was said, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Nothing' makes the statement negative, so the tag is positive. The subject pronoun for 'nothing/something/everything' is 'it'. The auxiliary verb is 'was'. Tag: was it.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'He ought to apologize, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: Modal verbs are repeated in the tag. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: oughtn't he.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Hardly anyone passed the test, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Hardly' makes the statement negative. The subject 'anyone' is replaced by 'they'. The tense is Simple Past, so use 'did'. Tag: did they.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Don't make any noise, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: For negative imperative sentences ('Don't...'), the tag is usually positive: 'will you'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'You have done your homework, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The auxiliary verb is 'have' (Present Perfect). The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: haven't you.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Everyone knows the answer, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Everyone' is replaced by 'they'. The statement is Simple Present (positive), so the tag is negative. With 'they', 'do' is used. Tag: don't they.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'The police arrived late, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The noun 'police' is always plural, so the pronoun used is 'they'. The statement is Simple Past (positive), so the tag is negative. Tag: didn't they.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'I used to play tennis, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: For 'used to' statements, the tag can be 'didn't' or 'usedn't'. 'Didn't' is more common and safer in exams. Tag: didn't I.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'They will attend the conference, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The auxiliary verb is 'will'. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative ('will not' = 'won't'). Tag: won't they.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'We need a break, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Need' as a main verb (Simple Present) uses 'do/does' in the tag. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: don't we. (Note: 'needn't we' is only correct if 'need' is used as a modal verb).

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'There is a problem, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: When the statement starts with 'There' + 'be', the tag uses 'there' as the pronoun. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: isn't there.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'I have little money, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Little' and 'Few' (without 'a') are inherently negative words, making the statement negative. Therefore, the tag must be positive. 'Have' is the main verb (Simple Present meaning 'possess'), so the auxiliary 'do' is technically needed, but in the case of 'I have', 'have I' is an accepted positive tag in British English. However, if 'have' acts as the main verb, 'don't I' is correct. **For exams, the strict negative rule applies:** 'Little' makes it negative. Auxiliary 'have' (as main verb) means Simple Present, so **do I** is the safest answer. But since 'have I' is an option and 'little' makes the clause negative, **have I** is chosen to reflect the auxiliary use of 'have' or 'do' when dealing with quantification. Let's stick to the auxiliary rule: 'little' makes it negative, auxiliary is 'have' (common usage). Tag: have I.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Let us not wait for him, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: For sentences starting with 'Let us' or 'Let's', whether positive or negative, the fixed question tag is usually 'shall we'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'We had a great time, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Had' here is the main verb (Simple Past meaning 'experienced'). Thus, the auxiliary verb 'did' is used. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: didn't we.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'No one came to the rescue, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'No one' makes the statement negative. 'No one' is replaced by the pronoun 'they'. The statement is Simple Past, so the tag is positive: 'did they'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'I need your help, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Need' is used as a main verb (Simple Present). The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: don't I.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'This is my bag, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: Demonstrative pronouns 'This/That' are replaced by the pronoun 'it' in the tag. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: isn't it.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'The weather seems fine, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'The weather' (singular, non-living) is replaced by 'it'. The statement is Simple Present ('seems'), so use 'does'. The statement is positive, so the tag is negative. Tag: doesn't it.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Sit down, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: This is a positive imperative sentence (command/request). The tag is usually 'will you' or 'won't you'. 'Will you' is generally accepted.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'I am not ready, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: The statement is negative ('am not'), so the tag must be positive. Tag: am I. (The 'aren't I' exception only applies to positive 'I am' statements).

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Few people understood the context, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Few' (without 'a') is a negative word, making the statement negative. 'People' is replaced by 'they'. The statement is Simple Past ('understood'), so the tag is positive: 'did they'.

question.en: Choose the correct question tag: 'Somebody has taken my book, _____?'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Somebody' is replaced by the pronoun 'they'. The statement is positive (Present Perfect), so the tag is negative. With 'they', 'have' is used. Tag: haven't they.

explanation.en: Rule: 'Neither' and 'Either' are used only for **two** items. For three or more, 'None' (negative) or 'Any' (positive/question) should be used. 'Neither of the three' should be 'None of the three'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'He gave a brief speech, and _____ point was highly effective.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each' is used when emphasizing the individual item within a group (stressing individuality). 'Every' views the group as a whole. Here, the focus is on the effectiveness of **separate** points.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Every man / and every woman / are entitled to vote. / No Error.'

en: are entitled to vote. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: are entitled to vote. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: When 'Each' or 'Every' precedes two or more subjects joined by 'and', the verb is singular. 'are entitled' should be 'is entitled'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'I asked three people, but _____ of them knew the answer.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'None' (meaning 'not any') is used when referring to three or more items. 'Neither' is only for two.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Each student / must submit / their assignment by Monday. / No Error.'

en: their assignment by Monday. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: their assignment by Monday. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each student' is singular. The possessive pronoun must also be singular and gender-neutral (if gender is unknown). 'their' should be 'his or her' or more formally 'his'. In modern English, 'their' is often accepted as a gender-neutral singular pronoun, but in formal grammar (SSC CGL), it is usually considered an error for 'his/her'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'They sold _____ house in the neighborhood.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Every' is used when referring to a large number of items and emphasizing the totality of the group ('all the houses'). It takes a singular noun ('house').

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'You can borrow / either of these / five books from the library. / No Error.'

en: five books from the library. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Either' is used only for **two** items. Since there are 'five books', 'Either of these' should be 'Any of these'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: '_____ employee received a personal congratulatory note.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each' emphasizes the individuality of the recipients and is followed by a singular noun ('employee').

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The boys / are playing / each one in his turn. / No Error.'

en: each one in his turn. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each' can follow a plural noun/pronoun to refer to the group's members individually. 'His' agrees with the singular sense of 'each one'. The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'We have two cars, and _____ of them is red.'

explanation.en: Rule: The verb 'is' is singular. 'Neither of' is followed by a plural noun ('cars') but takes a singular verb and means 'not one or the other' (negative).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The jury members / gave their / unanimous verdict. / No Error.'

explanation.en: Rule: The collective noun 'jury' is used as plural ('members') and followed by the plural pronoun 'their'. This is correct. (If 'jury' were singular, the pronoun would be 'its'.)

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: '_____ sentence was checked by the editor for grammar mistakes.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each' is followed by a singular countable noun ('sentence') and emphasizes the checking of every single unit separately.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'You can take / any of the / two dresses you like. / No Error.'

en: two dresses you like. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Any' is generally used for three or more. Since there are 'two dresses', 'any of the' should be 'either of the'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'We visit our grandparents _____ summer.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Every' is often used with time expressions (day, week, summer, year) to mean 'each one in a sequence'.

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Either of / the parents / is responsible for their childâ€™s behavior. / No Error.'

en: is responsible for their childâ€™s behavior. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: is responsible for their childâ€™s behavior. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Either of' is singular, so the verb 'is' is correct. The possessive pronoun should also be singular: 'their' should be 'his or her'. In formal grammar (SSC CGL), 'their' is an error here.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'We planted trees on _____ side of the road.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each' is often used when referring to two extremes or sides of something ('each side of the street', 'each end of the room').

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'They gave / both the students / a certificate and a trophy. / No Error.'

en: a certificate and a trophy. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Both' is correctly used to refer to two people/items ('the students'). The sentence is correct.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'I am afraid that _____ of his two theories is correct.'

explanation.en: Rule: The context ('two theories' and 'is correct' singular verb) demands 'Neither' (not one and not the other).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Every of / the players / was injured during the match. / No Error.'

en: was injured during the match. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Every' cannot be followed directly by 'of'. Only 'Each' or 'One' can use the structure: 'Each of the players'. 'Every of' should be 'Every player' (if the singular noun/verb is used) or 'Each of the players' (if referring to individuals within the group).

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'The prize was distributed to _____ participant present.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Every' is used when emphasizing the totality of a group, focusing on the group rather than the individuals. It is followed by a singular noun ('participant').

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'Each of / the reasons given / for the delay were convincing. / No Error.'

en: for the delay were convincing. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: for the delay were convincing. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each of' requires a singular verb. 'were convincing' should be 'was convincing'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'You have two pencils; you may use _____ one.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Either' is used for a choice between two items ('this one or that one').

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'I want / every child / to know that they are special. / No Error.'

en: to know that they are special. / No Error

correctAnswer.en: to know that they are special. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Every child' is singular. The pronoun 'they' is technically plural, but is often used in speech and modern casual writing as a gender-neutral singular. In strict SSC grammar, 'they' might be marked as an error for 'he or she is special'. However, since the error is often subjective, 'No Error' can be accepted given the modern shift towards inclusive language.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'He did not win, but _____ of the losses taught him a lesson.'

explanation.en: Rule: 'Each' is used when emphasizing the individual action or event (each separate loss provided a lesson).

question.en: Identify the part of the sentence that contains an error: 'The train stops / at every / of the three stations. / No Error.'

en: of the three stations. / No Error

explanation.en: Rule: 'Every' cannot be followed by 'of the'. It should be 'at each of the three stations' or 'at every station'.

question.en: Fill in the blank with the appropriate Distributive: 'The twin sisters look exactly alike; _____ one is easy to identify.'

explanation.en: Rule: The context ('exactly alike') implies a negative situation (difficult to identify). Since there are two sisters, 'neither' (meaning 'not one or the other') is correct. The verb 'is' also supports the singular distributive.
